Purpose and Scope

The purpose of this policy, procedure, and statement of commitment is to demonstrate Hi Five Community Services’ commitment the safety of the children in its care.

Legislation, regulations and standards relevant to this policy and procedure include, but are not necessarily limited to:

  • National Disability Insurance Scheme Act 2013
  • National Disability Insurance Scheme (Provider Registration and Practice Standards) Rules 2018 [F2020C00051]
  • Disability Inclusion Act 2018
  • NDIS Practice Standards and Quality Indicators – Provision of Supports - Safety

Organisational documents relevant to this policy and procedure:

  • Human Resources Policy and Procedure
  • Participants Charter
  • Feedback, Compliments and Complaints Policy and Procedure
  • Records and Information Management Policy and Procedure
  • Privacy and Confidentiality Policy and Procedure
  • Risk Management Policy and Procedure
  • Participants Incident Management Policy and Procedure

This policy and procedure applies to all potential and existing participants, their family members, carers and other supporters, as well as all staff of Hi Five Community Services.

Hi Five Community Services’ Commitment to Child Safety

Hi Five Community Services is committed to child safety.

Hi Five Community Services wants children to be safe, happy and empowered. We support and respect all children, as well as our staff.

Hi Five Community Services is committed to the safety, participation and empowerment of all children.

Hi Five Community Services has zero tolerance of child abuse, and all allegations and safety concerns will be treated very seriously and consistently with our robust policies and procedures.

Hi Five Community Services has legal and moral obligations to contact authorities when we are worried about a child’s safety, which we follow rigorously.

Hi Five Community Services is committed to preventing child abuse and identifying risks early, and removing and reducing these risks.

Hi Five Community Services has robust human resources and recruitment practices for all staff. Hi Five Community Services is committed to regularly training and educating our staff on child abuse risks.

Hi Five Community Services supports and respects all children, as well as our staff. Hi Five Community Services is committed to the cultural safety of Aboriginal children, the cultural safety of children from culturally and/or linguistically diverse backgrounds, and to providing a safe environment for children with a disability.

Hi Five Community Services has specific policies, procedures and training in place that support our staff to achieve these commitments.

Staff who believe a child is at immediate risk of abuse must phone 000.

 

Policy

This policy and procedure is intended to empower children who are vital and active participants in Hi Five Community Services. Hi Five Community Services involves them when making decisions, especially about matters that directly affect them. Hi Five Community Services listens to their views and respects what they have to say.

Hi Five Community Services promotes diversity and tolerance in our organisation, and people from all walks of life and cultural backgrounds are welcome. In particular, Hi Five Community Services:

  • promotes the cultural safety, participation and empowerment of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children;
  • promotes the cultural safety, participation and empowerment of children from culturally and/or linguistically diverse backgrounds; and
  • ensures that children with a disability are safe and can participate equally.

This policy and procedure guides Hi Five Community Services’ staff on how to behave with children accessing Hi Five Community Services’ services.

All Hi Five Community Services staff must agree to abide by Hi Five Community Services’ Staff Code of Conduct, which specifies the standards of conduct required when working with children. All staff, as well as children and their families, are given the opportunity to contribute to the development of the Code of Conduct.

 

Procedures

Training and supervision

Training and education is important to ensure that everyone in Hi Five Community Services understands that child safety is everyone’s responsibility.

Hi Five Community Services’ culture aims for all staff (in addition to parents/carers and children) to feel confident and comfortable in discussing any allegations of child abuse or child safety concerns. Hi Five Community Services trains staff to identify, assess, and minimise risks of child abuse and to detect potential signs of child abuse.

Hi Five Community Services supports staff through ongoing supervision to develop their skills to protect children from abuse; and promote the cultural safety of Aboriginal and Torre Strait Islander children, the cultural safety of children from linguistically and/or diverse backgrounds, and the safety of children with a disability.

New employees will be supervised regularly to ensure that they understand Hi Five Community Services’ commitment to child safety and that everyone has a role to play in protecting children from abuse, as well as checking that their behaviour towards children is safe and appropriate (please refer to Hi Five Community Services’ Staff Code of Conduct to understand appropriate behaviour further).

Any inappropriate behaviour will be reported through appropriate channels, including the NDIS Commission and Vic Police, depending on the severity and urgency of the matter.

Recruitment

Hi Five Community Services takes all reasonable steps to employ skilled people to work with children. Hi Five Community Services develops selection criteria and advertisements that clearly demonstrate Hi Five Community Services’ commitment to child safety and an awareness of Hi Five Community Services’ social and legislative responsibilities. Hi Five Community Services understands its ethical and legislative obligations when recruiting staff.

Hi Five Community Services actively encourages applications from Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples, people from culturally and linguistically diverse backgrounds and people with a disability.

All people engaged in child-related work are required to hold a Working with Children Check and to provide evidence of this Check.

Hi Five Community Services carries out reference checks and police record checks to ensure that it recruits the right people. See Hi Five Community Services’ Human Resources Policy and Procedure for more information on this process.

If during the recruitment process a person’s records indicate a criminal history, the person will be given the opportunity to provide further information and context.

Fair Procedures for Staff

The safety and wellbeing of children is Hi Five Community Services’ primary concern. Hi Five Community Services is also fair and just to staff. The decisions that Hi Five Community Services makes when recruiting, assessing incidents, and undertaking disciplinary action will always be thorough, transparent, and based on evidence.

Hi Five Community Services records all allegations of abuse and safety concerns in accordance with its incident management policies and procedures. All records are securely stored, in accordance with Hi Five Community Services’ Records and Information Management Policy and Procedure.

If an allegation of abuse or a safety concern is raised, Hi Five Community Services provides updates to children and families on progress and any actions that the organisation takes.

Privacy

All personal information considered or recorded will respect the privacy of the individuals involved, whether they be staff, parents or children, unless there is a risk to someone’s safety. Hi Five Community Services has safeguards and practices in place to ensure any personal information is protected. Everyone is entitled to know how this information is recorded, what will be done with it, and who will have access to it, in accordance with Hi Five Community Services’ Privacy and Confidentiality Policy and Procedure.

Legislative Responsibilities

Hi Five Community Services takes its legal responsibilities seriously, including:

  • Failure to disclose: Reporting child sexual abuse is a community-wide responsibility. All adults in Vic who have a reasonable belief that an adult has committed a sexual offence against a child under 16 have an obligation to report that information to the Police;[5]
  • Failure to protect: People of authority in Hi Five Community Services will commit an offence if they know of a substantial risk of child sexual abuse and have the power or responsibility to reduce or remove the risk, but negligently fail to do so;.[6] and
  • Any staff that are mandatory reporters must comply with their duties.[7]

Risk Management

Hi Five Community Services proactively manages risks of abuse to children accessing its services.

Hi Five Community Services has risk management strategies in place to identify, assess, and take steps to minimise child abuse risks, which include risks posed by physical environments (for example, any doors that can lock), and online environments (for example, no staff or volunteer is to have contact with a child supported by the organisation on social media). These strategies will be documented in Hi Five Community Services’ Risk Management Plans, in accordance with its Risk Management Policy and Procedure.

Allegations, concerns, and complaints

Hi Five Community Services takes all allegations seriously and has practices in place to investigate them thoroughly and quickly. Hi Five Community Services staff are trained to deal appropriately with allegations.

Hi Five Community Services works to ensure all children, families, and staff know what to do and who to tell if they observe abuse or are a victim, and if they notice inappropriate behaviour.

Hi Five Community Services staff and stakeholders all have a responsibility to report an allegation of abuse if they have a reasonable belief that an incident took place (see information about Failure to Disclose, above).

If an adult has a reasonable belief that an incident has occurred they must report the incident. Factors contributing to reasonable belief may be:

  • a child states they or someone they know has been abused (noting that sometimes the child may in fact be referring to themselves);
  • behaviour consistent with that of an abuse victim is observed (see Hi Five Community Services’ Participants Incident Management Policy and Procedure);[8]
  • someone else has raised a suspicion of abuse but is unwilling to report it; and
  • observing suspicious behaviour.

Monitoring and Review

This policy and procedure will be reviewed at least annually, or following any significant incident, by the Management Team, and will incorporate participants and other stakeholder feedback.

Hi Five Community Services’ Continuous Improvement Plan will be used to record and monitor progress of any improvements identified.

Hi Five Community Services will review and monitor its commitment to child safety and relevant policies and procedures in accordance with the Internal Review and External Audit Schedule. This schedule includes reviewing service planning and delivery activities, which incorporate participants and stakeholder participation and assesses feedback provided to and by participants and stakeholders.

Service delivery and satisfaction surveys will assess:

  • participants and other stakeholder awareness of their rights and the extent to which they feel safe and supported by Hi Five Community Services; and
  • participants and other stakeholder satisfaction with Hi Five Community Services’ child safety processes.
